channel.title: NYT > Global Home
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Turkish Pianist Sentenced for Twitter Postings
item.description: Fazil Say, given a 10-month suspended sentence for insulting Islam and offending Muslims, said the accusations against him offended human rights.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Attackers Strike Across Iraq as Elections Approach
item.description: Nearly 20 separate attacks killed at least 37 people on Monday, a bloody backdrop to the approach of the nation’s first local elections since the American military withdrawal.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO

item.title: Greece Reaches New Deal With Lenders
item.description: The agreement, after nearly two weeks of tense negotiations, includes thousands of layoffs in the civil service.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Afghanistan Opium Production Increases for 3rd Year
item.description: The increase, reported Monday in a United Nations assessment, raised the specter that Afghanistan could become, in the words of one official, “the world’s first true narco-state.”
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Attacks Across Iraq Kill 27 People, Officials Say
item.description: A series of attacks in several cities across the country, many involving car bombs, killed 27 people on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Venezuelans Elect Maduro to Succeed Chávez
item.description: Nicolás Maduro, the handpicked political heir to Hugo Chávez, won election to serve the remainder of Mr. Chávez’s term, officials said. Mr. Maduro’s opponent, Henrique Capriles Radonski, demanded a recount.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: At a polling station in Caracas, ballots were emptied onto a table for counting.

item.title: In Surprise, Recovery in China Loses Steam
item.description: The economy expanded by just 7.7 percent during the first three months of the year, compared with a year earlier, falling short of expectations.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Chinese G.D.P. for First Quarter Shows Signs of Slowdown
item.description: The economy expanded by just 7.7 percent during the first three months of the year, compared with a year earlier, falling short of expectations.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: New Leak Found at Fukushima Nuclear Plant
item.description: The newest leak will force the operator of the nuclear plant in Japan to postpone the removal of contaminated water for several days.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: ArtsBeat: Sir Colin Davis, British Conductor, Dies at 85
item.description: Sir Colin left an indelible mark on the London Symphony Orchestra. He championed Sibelius and Berlioz, and revived Mozart as a symphonic mainstay.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ
item.media:credit: Matthew Murphy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sir Colin Davis conducted the London Symphony Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall in New York City in 2011.

item.title: Adam Scott Wins Playoff, Becoming First Australian to Win Masters
item.description: Adam Scott, beating Ángel Cabrera in a playoff, exorcised the memories of Greg Norman’s collapse at the 1996 Masters and his own collapse at the 2012 British Open.
item.dc:creator: By KAREN CROUSE
item.media:description: Adam Scott after winning the Masters. Scott shot a three-under 69 on Sunday, with another Australian, Jason Day, finishing third, just two strokes back.

item.title: Party Rifts Complicate Chances for Gun Bill Passage
item.description: Divisions over a measure to extend background checks for gun buyers are undermining support for what was seen as a compromise deal to ease passage of a broader bill.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: Senators Patrick J. Toomey, left, a Republican, and Joe Manchin III, a Democrat, appeared on “Face the Nation” on Sunday.

item.title: As Court Considers Gene Patents, Case May Overlook Relevant Issues
item.description: The Supreme Court is poised to take up the question of whether human genes can be patented. But some say advances in the field may blunt the impact of its ruling.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW POLLACK
item.media:description: A Myriad Genetics scientist preparing samples for DNA sequencing. The Supreme Court will hear a case on Monday, involving the company, on whether human genes can be patented.

item.title: Economic Memo: In Divided Market, the Bigger the Companies, the Better They Fare
item.description: American giants are benefiting from productivity gains and renewed growth in China and other overseas markets, allowing them to increase profits even if business at home remains lackluster.
item.dc:creator: By NELSON D. SCHWARTZ

item.title: On Par: 12 Over at Age 14? For Guan, a Week to Grow On
item.description: China’s Guan Tianlang got a standing ovation and big cheers from the gallery on the 18th green after finishing for a total of 12-over 300.
item.dc:creator: By KAREN CROUSE
item.media:description: Guan Tianlang, 14, was the low amateur. He finished three shots behind Phil Mickelson and five behind last year’s champion, Bubba Watson.

item.title: U.S. Visa Delays Put Safety Out of Afghan Interpreters’ Reach
item.description: Afghans who worked for American forces have found themselves without military protection and facing a backlog for visas that could help give them protection.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sulaiman, a combat interpreter, in Kabul, Afghanistan. An American visa has remained beyond his grasp, despite years of effort.

item.title: On Par: Adam Scott and Australia Win First Masters
item.description: Adam Scott of Australia won his first green jacket on the second playoff hole at the Masters. Scott and Angel Cabrera each birdied on the 18th hole of the final round to compete in a sudden-death playoff.
item.dc:creator: By NAILA-JEAN MEYERS
item.media:description: Adam Scott of Australia after winning the Masters.

item.title: Google and Europe Reach Deal on Search Results
item.description: Google has for the first time agreed to legally binding changes to its search results after an antitrust investigation by European regulators.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

item.title: Majuli Journal: Indian Island Shrinks as Brahmaputra Swells and Sways
item.description: The Brahmaputra River, a critical laboratory in climate studies, is fast eroding an island in Assam that it has encircled and sustained for ages.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Enrico Fabian for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man wove bamboo to build a wall for a hut. The Brahmaputra River encircles the island of Majuli, home to about 170,000 people and dozens of monasteries.

item.title: Deadly Attacks Strike Somalia’s Capital, Mogadishu
item.description: Islamists militants known as the Shabab carried out a suicide attack on the court complex, and a bomb was detonated later on the airport road.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM
item.media:description: Mothers ran with their children Sunday after a suicide attack on the court complex in Mogadishu, Somalia. Later, a blast hit an international convoy, officials said.

item.title: Elites Flock to Anti-Euro Party, Alternative for Germany
item.description: Alternative for Germany, started by a Hamburg economics professor, could play the role of spoiler in the September elections.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Members of Alternative for Germany, which held a party congress on Sunday in a Berlin hotel.

item.title: Justin Trudeau Elected Leader of Liberal Party of Canada
item.description: Justin Trudeau, 41, the son of Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who was prime minister for 15 years, is faced with reviving a party that is no longer dominant in federal politics.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Undercover BBC Trip to North Korea Is Criticized
item.description: Reporters who joined students from the London School of Economics on a North Korean trip did not disclose their true purpose and filmed an undercover documentary, the university said.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: Intel Tries to Find a Foothold Beyond PCs
item.description: The world’s largest semiconductor maker is struggling to adapt as PC sales collapse, users rely more on mobile phones and tablets, and cloud computing expands.
item.dc:creator: By QUENTIN HARDY
item.media:description: Paul Otellini announced his resignation as the president and chief executive of Intel last November.

item.title: Italian American Museum Seeks New Chance to Save the Past
item.description: The board of the Italian American Museum in the Little Italy neighborhood of Manhattan has drawn up plans to sell its building to a developer and relocate inside whatever structure replaces it.
item.dc:creator: By ROBIN POGREBIN
item.media:credit: Agaton Strom for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Italian American Museum, at Mulberry and Grand Streets.
